div.p: There are no free iPads: An Analysis of Survey Scams as a Business
Jason W. Clark and Damon McCoy George Mason University (GMU)
Spam is a profit-fueled enterprise Spam campaigns lure users to click on enticing
posts Common method for monetization is survey
scams offering free iPads and Costco Gift Cards Cyber-criminals are focusing on Facebook Links lead to ad networks that bombard users
with surveys to collect personal/contact information -> sold to marketers
Sometimes (bit.ly) automation is used to hide the survey scam URL
Definition of Terms Cost-Per-Action or Lead Generation = Ad network that pays
their affiliates a commission for every survey that a user completes.
Offer = An enticing proposition that promises free gifts, products or services for those who click a link in a message.
Personally Identifiable Information (PII) SSN, First and Last Name, Full Address, DoB, Phone #, Gender, Interests

Future Work Attempt to estimate how much traffic is generated by
Facebook Spam Collaboration to utilize more/different spam feeds Incorporate better/more automation Contact ad networks to determine if they close down or
provide information on their affiliates that engage in abusing advertising
Conclusions Presented an empirical study of Facebook spam Revealing 73% of the working spam URLs in our Facebook
spam were monetized by survey scams sponsored by Ad Networks
Based on our manual analysis of 129 unique spam URLs over 50% were traced to: Amung.us, CPAlead, ClickBanner, and LifeStreet Media
Carbon Dating Results: Average age of URLs was 9 months Indicates ad networks are not proactively detecting/blocking affiliates
Preliminary Results: Potential point to demonetize the spam ecosystem by intervening at these ad networks that sponsor spam
